--- title: "Sampling Variability -- The Heart of Statistical Inference" format: revealjs: theme: style.scss editor: visual --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 3em; color: #000000;"} Salaries of football coaches ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/coach-salary.jpg){width=570} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: # Individual Samples ## Each group has a different sample of 25 UC & CSU coach salaries. :::::::: columns :::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #000000;"} **First**... ::: - each person samples 10 salaries - calculate the median - write your median on a post-it note - place your median on the class plot :::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: :::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #000000;"} **Then**... ::: everyone works together to calculate the median of all 25 salaries :::: :::::::: ## {background-color="#B6CADA"} ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"} Would you feel comfortable inferring that the median salary of your sample is close to the median salary of ***all*** UC & CSU coaches? :::
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #000000;"} Why or why not? ::: ## Precision & Accuracy :::::: columns ::: {.column width="55%"} ![](images/accuracy_vs_precision.jpg) ::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} - Random sampling ensures our point estimates are accurate.
- Larger sample sizes ensure our point estimates are precise. ::: :::::: ## Statistical Inference There were 252 "Head Coaches" at University of California and California State Universities in 2021 (that satisfied my search criteria)
::::::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} **Median salary for all 252 coaches** $137,619 ::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: :::: {.column width="45%"} ::: fragment Was the median of your sample of 25 coaches a good estimate of the salary for all 252 coaches? ::: :::: ::::::: ## Sampling Framework *population* -- collection of observations / individuals we are interested in *population parameter* -- numerical summary about the population that is unknown but you wish you knew . . .
*sample* -- a collection of observations from the population *sample statistic* -- a summary statistic computed from a sample that *estimates* the unknown population parameter. ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"} Statistical Inference Reasoning ::: :::: incremental ::: small - If the sampling is done at random - then the sample should be representative of the population - any result based on the sample can generalize to the population - the point estimate is a "good guess" of the unknown population parameter ::: :::: . . . ::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #ed8402;"} Every group had a random sample of 25 coach salaries, so why were some of the medians really far off? ::: # Repeated Samples ## Why sample more than once? . . .
::::::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} What do we get when we take multiple samples? ::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: :::: {.column width="55%"} ::: fragment A distribution of statistics! ::: :::: :::::::
:::::::: columns :::: {.column width="40%"} ::: fragment Why do we want a distribution of statistics? ::: :::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: :::: {.column width="55%"} ::: fragment Understanding the *variability* of a statistic is the heart of statistical inference! ::: :::: :::::::: ## Virtual Sampling ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="false"} rep_sample_n(coaches, size = 25, reps = 1, replace = FALSE) ``` :::

$\vdots$ ## {background-color="#B6CADA"} ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"} Distribution of 1000 medians from samples of 25 coaches ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](week7-day1_files/figure-revealjs/samp-25-plot-1.png){width=60%} ::: ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"} Sampling Distributions ::: - Visualize the effect of sampling variation on the distribution of any point estimate - In this case, the sample median! - We can use sampling distributions to make statements about what values we can typically expect. . . . ::: callout-caution # Sampling distribution vs. Sample distribution Be careful! A **sampling distribution** is different from a *sample's distribution*! ::: ## {background-color="#B6CADA"} ::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #000000;"} Distributions of 1000 medians from different sample sizes ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](week7-day1_files/figure-revealjs/samp-plots-1.png){width=80%} ::: :::
**What differences do you see?** ## ::: {style="font-size: 1.75em; color: #000000;"} Variability for Different Sample Sizes ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em; color: #000000;"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Sample Size Standard Error of Median
25 19408.079

100 8279.311
````` ::: ::: ::: . . . ::: small - Standard errors quantify the variability of point estimates - As a general rule, as sample size increases, the standard error decreases. ::: . . . ::: callout-caution # Standard error vs. Standard deviation Careful! <script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
